title: How to Make a Neon Pine Cone Place Card Holder

steps.headline: Brush off any debris from each pine cone.
steps.description: Inspect each cone for damage and discard any that don't meet your standards.

steps.headline: Cover a flat surface with newspaper to create a workspace.
steps.description: Find an area for the pine cones to dry. Cover the dry area with newspaper too.

steps.headline: Pour the paint into the paper bowl or plate.
steps.description: Grab a few heavy duty paper towels. Keep the paper towels on hand in case the paint drips or you need to remove excess paint from the brush. Excess paint can be removed from the brush by simply pressing the brush against the rim of the plate or bowl before moving the brush to the cone.

steps.headline: Dip the paintbrush into the paint.
steps.description: Gently apply paint to the tip of each of the pine cone wedges.

steps.headline: Transfer the painted pine cone to the dry area.
steps.description: Allow it to fully dry before adding the place card.

steps.headline: Consider whether you want to hand write each guest’s name on the card or if you’d prefer to have them laser printed.
steps.description: The choice will impact the type of place card you use. Be sure to purchase enough cards for your party––spares always come in handy. Buy a special pen, perhaps even a calligraphy pen, if you plan to hand write each place card.

steps.headline: Create the place cards by either typing names and printing from your computer or by writing names on individual place cards by hand.
steps.description: Keep finished place cards in a safe area until ready to be joined with the pine cone.

methods.name: Assembling and Placing Your Place Cards

steps.headline: Wedge one place card into the top of the dried pine cone.
steps.description: Each placement will not be perfect, so just look for natural spots in the cone that will hold the place card neatly on top of the pine cone.

steps.headline: Double check each pine cone to ensure it has fully dried before leaving it at the guest’s place.

text: Painting the Pine Cones Brush off any debris from each pine cone. Inspect each cone for damage and discard any that don't meet your standards. Cover a flat surface with newspaper to create a workspace. Find an area for the pine cones to dry. Cover the dry area with newspaper too. Pour the paint into the paper bowl or plate. Grab a few heavy duty paper towels. Keep the paper towels on hand in case the paint drips or you need to remove excess paint from the brush. Excess paint can be removed from the brush by simply pressing the brush against the rim of the plate or bowl before moving the brush to the cone. Dip the paintbrush into the paint. Gently apply paint to the tip of each of the pine cone wedges. Transfer the painted pine cone to the dry area. Allow it to fully dry before adding the place card. Making the Place Cards Consider whether you want to hand write each guest’s name on the card or if you’d prefer to have them laser printed. The choice will impact the type of place card you use. Be sure to purchase enough cards for your party––spares always come in handy. Buy a special pen, perhaps even a calligraphy pen, if you plan to hand write each place card. Create the place cards by either typing names and printing from your computer or by writing names on individual place cards by hand. Keep finished place cards in a safe area until ready to be joined with the pine cone. Assembling and Placing Your Place Cards Wedge one place card into the top of the dried pine cone. Each placement will not be perfect, so just look for natural spots in the cone that will hold the place card neatly on top of the pine cone. Double check each pine cone to ensure it has fully dried before leaving it at the guest’s place. Finished.
